complaint:
I’m hoping you can help me with an on-going problem we are having in my neighborhood here in Columbia County.  When the adjoining property was rezoned to Manufacturing, we were assured by our local Planning Dept. that no pollution  of any kind would be allow to affect our neighboring residential properties. Now they tell me they don’t have the ability to do anything about a cabinet shop that is allowing what smells like strong paint fumes to be exhausted from their shop. At times it is so strong that we can’t stay out in our backyard. Unfortunately, we are only separated by a chain link fence. We normally leave our windows open this time of the year and let our whole house attic fan cool our house. We can’t even do that when a slight shift in the prevailing winds from the southwest brings those fumes right into the house.  Not only do I have to deal with the headaches I get from exposure to these fumes , but we now have out 1 year old grandson living with us and I am extremely worried about the effect that these VOC’s could possibly have on his development.  Is there any way that the state can check to see if they have any sort of filter on their exhaust system and if so, is it working properly ? The Environmental Compliance folks in Columbia County tell me that they are not equipped to do air monitoring and suggested I contact the EPD. 
I have attached a map showing the location of the business, Cedar Ridge Cabinet Company at 321 UN Court, as it relates to my house location at 5168 Bluegrass Trail , Grovetown, Ga. 30813 
I’m hoping if your department is not the correct group to handle this type of problem, you can point me in the right direction of who I need to contact.
I would appreciate any help that you can provide.

They are still burning creosote. I know what it smells like. I don’t care if anyone says there not I know they are because I smell it. I'm standing outside watching the smoke and smelling it.  

Gina Ward followed up 9/4 in the AM: Good Morning, 

I have been fielding many complaints and concerns about GRP and the smell of creosote in the air.
It is sad that our community is well versed in identifying the different odors that GRP emits. I am fully aware that your division does not address odors, but in our experience with GRP, if it smells like a skunk, it probably is!
They are backing semi-trucks into the warehouse, and I wonder if they are hiding something. There are dark streaks in the fuel pile as well. This week very dark smoke has been reported coming from the stack. In the rail car "parking lot" in Athens there are railcars loaded full of what appears to be chipped railties.
I checked EOS and can find no permits for National Salvage.

I would like to know where GRP's fuel is coming from. In my understanding, they are supposed to keep records of the origin. Am I correct, and can the public access these records? We feel we have a right to know what is going on at the plant, as their operations affect our daily living.

Thank you for your help,

Gina Ward

"Hello,

I live near Peachtree City, GA, and we went to Jekyll Island this week.  On the way back, we decided to take back roads and we drove through Jesup.
We noticed a horrible smell.  Within 10 minutes, we both had sore throats, coughing and burning eyes.  We immediately left the area.
We stopped for lunch in Rieverdale (?).  As soon as I stood up, I started coughing for 5 minutes and couldn’t catch my breath.  My mom immediately threw up.
I did some research to see what we were exposed to and saw about the Rayonier Mill and your name was attached.
I’m not sure if there is someone to contact - but people can’t near that and be healthy.  Something needs to be done.  If we got that sick being exposed for 10 minutes, it seems really dangerous for people who live there!
It’s a shame that businesses are allowed to act that way in poorer areas of the state where people are trapped to live. Actually it seems criminal.

I hope someone can help or know who can.

Thank you,
Melissa Howell
517 xxx-xxxx
"

complaint:
EPD received a request for assistance from Forsyth County in identifying the source of numerous (e.g. 100’s) of odor complaints they have been receiving in the area of the northern end of Ga Hwy 400 in Forsyth County.  In the area north of Hwy 369 (Brown’s Bridge Rd) up to Jot’em Down Road.  There is an Tyson (formerly American Proteins) Rendering Plant in the area, but the County claims they have not been able to determine the source of the odors. The odor is described as a putrid smell, possibly like septage, decaying animals, etc.
nearest WWTPs to see if they are land applying any biosolids to farmland in the area (may be available in Biosolids Management Plans).  Also maybe check with DOAg  (Jennifer Wren) to see if she is aware of anyone land applying soil amendments in the area.  Maybe we should also check with Hampton Creek WRF to make sure they are not discharging without a permit again.

I spoke with the Dept of Utilities today concerning this issue which has been going on for the last two weeks.  Apparently this is a problem that has been going on at different times during the year for years now.  I know that it was going on 21 years ago when I moved to Cumming, however, it usually doesn’t last this long and some years it is worse than others.  This year just happens to be one of the worse.  Daily it is a topic on the internet because people do not know what it is or what is going on.  The problem is the City of Cumming is apparently doing nothing to correct the problem.

Let’s get out of the way that it is not the lake and the water - that is a whole other issue which is being worked on by the utility company.  

It is Tyson or Koch, and most of the citizens know it.  Their system (that they own) located near the fairgrounds is the culprit, and it needs to be fixed.  As a resident of Cumming I should not have to put up with this because I do believe there is a solution to the problem.    If there are any type of air vents on that tank, there is probably a filtration system that would help get rid of the stench.  If in fact the problem can be fixed, Tyson needs to step up and correct it.  If they choose to ignore it the City of Cumming needs to force them to correct the problem or start enforcing a fine until it is corrected.

My house now reeks from this stench, my allegories are out of control, and I am just sick and tired of this problem going on year after year. Thank goodness my house is not on the market for sale, because there is no way anyone would want to buy property in the Cumming area. To the city, I say “Step Up and Do Something, (just because I know you can)”.

complaint:
From email:

Good Morning, 
 
I am new tom the Conyers area. We have been experiencing strong Hydrogen Sulfide fumes in our neighborhood. The odor has permeated into our house so strongly that it is affecting my families sleep. I do not have any gas lines in my home, so I reached out to neighbors only to learn they too have experienced the strong odors. I learned the neighborhood is located less than one mile from the Rockdale County Wastewater treatment facility located at 2420 Tatum Rd, Conyers, GA 30013. My neighbors and I would like to file a formal complaint and investigation to mitigate the release of gasses into our neighborhoods. Outside of contacting to the EPA to file formal air pollution complaints, what steps should we take to formalize this effort?

Clean Air Act
 
1. The socks in the bag back house have been changed out in two year,,,are leaking.  The Opacity Logs are being fudged
2. RTO monthly PM are not done or problems addressed
3. Several of the monthly and weekly inspection reports were not accurate and had other people name sign off that were forgery 
4. The unpolymerized waste from slabs containing large amount of Stryene contributing to emissions
5.  Imploded tank in the resin  storage room is leaking along with the pipes and vales causing emissions
6. The duct work that is supped to remove styrene emission from the inside the process is blocked and not working.
7. There is no ventilation liquid prep room causing emission
8. There is no ventilation in the bulk storage room causing emissions
9. No ventilation bulk hazardous material storage room.
10. The silo hold the different powered are blowing of silica dust which is out side the air permit
12.  The blower motor gasket and the emission control gasket
 
 
RCRA
 
1. Haz. Waste not stored properly with lids being left off in the hazardous waste
2. Make shift parts washer filled with acetone with no lids and no labels
3. Large amount waste slab mix sitting out side, no containment, no lids, no labels
4. Large amount of waste slab mix containing styrene be placed in open top open top dumpster and taken to the land fill.
5. The bakout box for the styrene mixture is not working properly.
6. Used plastic wrap that is used in the manufacturing process to protect the belt, is be place in a dumpster.  The smell is sickening and it has large slab mix on it.  Well over the RCRA limits
7. Universal waste not labeled
8. Used oil not labled.
 
Clean Water Act/RCRA/STORM WATER/SPCC
 
1.  There has been several over flow of the resin off load area.  The pit in the off load has over lowed and has large amount of styrene over the RQ and never reported.
2. The resin off load pump and area was clean with MEK,  Acetone and power washed soap.  There was over spray of water and chemical were waster over the spill containment and went into the storm drain. Never reported.
3. During the cleaning process above the wast went down in to the pit.  The pit was full of MEK, Acetone, water was then pumped the grass down down the storm drain.  The storm drain went the retention pond that then it was released into federal protected wet lands.
4.  The ponds of several times have been dug up because of contaminated soil witch was above the RQ on several chemical including styrene, MEK, Acetone.
5.  The trailer leak wast water treatment sludge which is high in Silica, going down the road witch caused exposure to particulate mater.

Complaint was received via email on July 27, 2020 from Megan Arias with US EPA Region 4:

"Every time a ship dock at East Coast Terminal to off load concrete our cars are coated with dust. This dust ,being on our cars, is safe to say inhaled by all the workers at Crescent towing and Moran Towing. These two businesses are next to each other. Since the first arrival of this ship with this cargo, we have had our cars cleaned by our employers. The bill for this is in the thousands each occurrence. I have pictures of the dust on my car. I have pictures of the dust on the cars in the parking lot. All of these pictures are time , date ,and location stamped. The human factor issue is , what is the long term exposure to this dust? The answer is Silicosis. This is a lung disease. Please respond to me on this matter. My new vehicle being covered is a concern. My health is another matter as well. This is a text book example of environmental pollution. I read it on you website. Lynn Skelton."

complaint:
Caller states that her house located behind East Coast asphalt in Brantley County. She has previously complained regarding visible emissions and odor and the conditions had improved, but are back to becoming a constant issue at her residence. She stated that the facility is running through the night almost every night and the odor and black smoke coming from them is very objectionable. 

She also stated that her pond (private) has a sheen on the water and it appears to have an oily residue that she believes is being caused by the lack of control devices at the asphalt plant, causing the particulate matter to accumulate in her pond. She also stated that at the firehouse adjacent to the asphalt plant, they have told her their cars are covered with a black dust they believe is coming from the plant.

I informed her that since the pond is private she would likely need to have a consultant look at it to determine what the issue was and to pull any water samples. I provided her with the number to UGA aquaculture for further advisement and provided her a list of pond consultants in the state of Georgia. I let her know that we could check into East Coast Asphalt to see if there were any compliance related issues that were contributing to the conditions she described.

She later sent me pictures of her pond via text message, which are attached to this complaint.
location: East Coast Asphalt, located on Hwy 82 in Brantley County.

I called my local Forestry Department about a month ago about a neighbor that is having truckloads of trees and brush brought to his property. He cuts it up and burns it. He’s Been doing this for years and it’s been uncomfortable but no big deal. I recently took custody of my three grandchildren one of whom has severe allergies and asthma. It’s so severe that I’ve had to remove all of my carpet and had an air purification system put in my home. When I made the call to the Forestry Dept. I was told they would take care of it because it’s not legal for this type of operation. The burning has continued. I was told to call the fire department if he started burning again. I called the fire department Saturday. They pulled in front of my house with lights on and all. Asked if I was referring to the neighbor two houses down. Was that necessary?  Really, they couldn’t see the smoke and flames?  Well, for the past two nights the neighbor is burning late at night. So now I have my 8 yr old grandson waking me up at 2:00 am telling me that he can’t breathe. Obviously we’re on stay at home orders so I can’t pick up and leave. He was diagnosed with an upper respiratory infection yesterday and we have an appointment for X-rays to test for pneumonia today. I’m sure I don’t have to explain my concern with this particular diagnosis at a time a virus is killing thousands of people a day. Could you please give me direction on as to how I should handle this problem?  If he’s burning illegally, why can’t he just be shut down?
